Top 10 Psychology Theories That Defy Common
Sense

6.text:
10. Agreeable People Are More Likely to Do
“Bad” Things

12.text:
Imagine you have two friends named Alex and
Daniel. Alex is pleasant and outgoing, while

16.text:
Daniel is cold and aloof. If someone asked
them to dole out electric shocks to a complete

21.text:
stranger, who do you think is more likely
to do it?

23.text:
Your first answer would probably be Daniel,
which is wrong according to an unpublished

27.text:
study in the Journal of Personality. The researchers
found that people who are agreeable and conscientious

32.text:
are more compliant with requests like “Shock
this person with electricity” compared to

37.text:
people who are contrarian and disagreeable.
Furthermore, those who have left-wing political

41.text:
views are also less compliant with such requests,
so if you know an ornery socialist they’re

46.text: the one you’d want to trust in this scenario.

48.text:
How’s this possible? Well, “agreeableness”
can be a double-edged sword: If you’re an

53.text:
agreeable person, you’re more likely to
go with the norm, whether that “norm”

56.text:
is morally questionable or not. If you’re
disagreeable, you’re more likely to be the

60.text:
questioning type. Now, this isn’t to say
that every Agreeable Alex is automatically

64.text:
“bad,” while everyone who’s a Disagreeable
Daniel is automatically “good.” People

69.text:
are much more complicated than that, and trying
to predict their future actions using one

73.text:
facet of their personality is ridiculous.
Generally, it’s better to figure out to

78.text:
what degree they’d be compliant with a norm,
rather than jump to hasty assumptions based

84.text:
9. Military Uniforms Alter Police Officers’
Psychology

89.text:
Unless you hid under a rock in 2014, you’re
probably aware of what happened in Ferguson,

93.text:
Missouri. But we’re not here to discuss
politics — we want to zero in on one particular

98.text:
aspect of the incident that may or may not
have contributed to it: The Ferguson police

104.text:
According to Maria Konnikova of The New Yorker,
people associate police officers in military-style

109.text:
gear (e.g. SWAT suits, fatigues) with aggression.
This seems commonsensical enough. But what’s

116.text:
really surprising is the effect of the uniforms
on the police themselves. Konnikova writes:

120.text:
“When (police officers) ‘dress up’ for
serious engagements, for example when donning

124.text:
SWAT gear to respond to a riot, they no longer
feel like law enforcement anymore but like

129.text:
part of a broader military machine.” Gives
a whole new meaning to “You are what you

135.text:
8. Your Language Affects Your Perception of
the World

139.text:
If we have “You are what you wear” we
also have “You are what you speak,” at

142.text:
least according to university professors Lera
Boroditsky and Aneta Pavlenko. For them, the

148.text:
language you use determines what you notice,
what you don’t notice, and how you categorize

152.text:
things. For example, since the Australian
Aboriginal language Guugu Yimithirr doesn’t

156.text:
have specific words for “left” and “right”
they say “The man to your west is my father.”

160.text:
Likewise, Russian distinguishes objects based
on shape rather than material, while Spanish

165.text: and German designate genders for objects.

167.text:
There are people who disagree with this idea.
John McWhorter, a linguist from Columbia University,

172.text:
argues that it’s not the language per se,
but the culture surrounding the language that

176.text:
explains why bilinguals seem to switch personalities
when they switch languages. Boroditsky counters

182.text:
this by saying that a language is just one
factor that shapes our worldview, and that

186.text:
learning languages changes our way of thinking
the way other forms of learning does. Whichever

190.text:
you believe, one thing’s for sure: Learning
a language other than the one you’re born

194.text:
with can be a life-changing experience — if
you let it be that way.

198.text:
7. Yawning Keeps Your Brain Alert (Among Other
Things)

203.text:
Next time your boss calls you out for yawning
in front of him, say “But sir, it helps

206.text:
me think!” Then smile inwardly as his eyes
glaze over you and wonder what’s going on.

211.text:
Seriously, though, there’s a good reason
you yawn, and it’s not always because you

215.text:
lack sleep. Andrew Gallup, an assistant professor
from the State University of New York’s

220.text:
psychology department, says that humans yawn
for the following reasons: to keep their own

223.text:
brains at an optimal temperature and become
more alert, to make other people more alert

227.text:
(which explains why “contagious yawning”
is a thing) and as a response to weaning off

232.text:
certain drugs, which explains why recovering
heroin addicts yawn a lot. Talk about a load

237.text: of useful functions for something so embarrassing!

240.text:
6. Liking Starbucks Coffee Has Nothing to
Do with “Quality”

245.text:
Ever wonder why people flock to Starbucks
the way piranhas flock to fresh meat? Maybe

249.text:
it’s because Starbucks coffee is superior,
quality-wise, to other types of coffee. Or

254.text:
maybe not: In a blind taste test, people think
Walmart’s $3.88 coffee tastes just as good

260.text:
as $8.88 Starbucks coffee! So what is the
secret to the latter’s popularity, if not

267.text:
Psychologist Dan Ariely, author of Predictably
Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our

271.text:
Decisions, thinks he knows the answer. In
his book, Ariely writes that Howard Schultz

275.text:
took great care to design Starbucks like a
“continental coffeehouse.” Basically,

279.text:
the coffee store’s great ambiance explains
why people keep coming back to the green-and-white

284.text:
two-tailed mermaid again and again. The fact
that Starbucks coffee is a rewarding and familiar

289.text:
splurge for caffeine-thirsty office workers
also helps.

296.text:
“Block social media.” “Don’t check
e-mail first thing in the morning.” If you’re

300.text:
a productivity junkie, chances are you’ve
come across these tips at some point. But

304.text:
it turns out they’re not gospel, at least
not for all people. One study by University

309.text:
of Copenhagen researchers showed that people
who watched a funny video before completing

313.text:
a task made fewer mistakes than the people
who were explicitly told not to watch the

317.text:
video beforehand. Given what we know about
Internet distractions, it should’ve worked

321.text: the other way around. So what gives?

324.text:
Six words: Human willpower is a finite resource.
You can only do the same thing over and over

329.text:
again for so long before you crack and get
sucked into the Internet wormhole. As Jenna

333.text:
Wortham writes in her New York Times piece
“I Took a Web Detour, and Now I Feel Better“:

337.text:
“Sometimes, I’ve found that losing myself
in the Web can be invigorating.”

341.text:
4. People Who Own More Aren’t Necessarily
Happier

345.text:
When we think of “happy” people, we tend
to think of those who have everything they

349.text:
could ever ask for: A big house, a nice car,
and everything else money can buy. But Dr.

354.text:
Tim Kasser, a psychology professor from Knox
College in Galesburg, Illinois, doesn’t

358.text:
think that’s the case. In an interview with
the American Psychological Association, Kasser

364.text:
says that materialistic people are less healthy,
less concerned about the environment, more

368.text:
selfish, have poorer academic performance
and have more money problems. This can be

373.text:
explained by the main reason behind materialism:
People want to own more, more and more when

378.text:
they try to overcompensate for something,
or protect themselves from a perceived threat.

382.text:
So the next time you meet someone with more
possessions than they can handle, maybe — just

386.text:
maybe — there’s more to that person than
meets the eye.

390.text:
3. When You Do Favors for Someone, You Tend
To Like Them More

393.text:
From what we know about “liking” someone
it usually works this way: If you do a favor

398.text:
for a person, that person will like you. Because,
hey, who doesn’t like being on the receiving

402.text:
end of favors? But Benjamin Franklin (yes,
that Benjamin Franklin) thought differently.

408.text:
Legend says that when a political opponent
insulted him, Franklin returned the favor

411.text:
by asking him to let Franklin borrow a book.
Flattered that Franklin — who was known

415.text:
for his good taste in books — asked him
that, the man accomplished the favor right

419.text: away and became a good friend of Franklin.

421.text:
Whether or not this story is true, the Ben
Franklin effect is definitely real. When a

426.text:
researcher challenged participants to an “intellectual
contest” and asked them to return the prize

430.text:
money to him afterwards, the participants
rated the researcher as more likeable. One

435.text:
possible explanation for this baffling phenomenon
is cognitive dissonance. We all want our thoughts,

440.text:
words and actions to be consistent with each
other. When we come across a situation causing

444.text:
an internal conflict between those three,
we feel uncomfortable and try to “equalize”

449.text:
the conflicting sides to relieve our discomfort.
To put this in the context of the Ben Franklin

454.text:
effect: Even if you dislike the person you’re
doing favors for, a part of you wants to like

459.text:
that person, because why else would you do
a favor for someone you don’t like?

463.text:
2. Being Able to Feel Depression Is a Good
Sign

466.text:
Let’s be clear on one thing first: We’re
not saying that depression sufferers shouldn’t

471.text:
seek help. If you have it, please seek professional
help.

475.text:
That said, there’s a reason people are capable
of experiencing depression in the first place.

480.text:
According to psychologist Jonathan Rottenberg,
our high and low moods balance each other

484.text:
out. Without the highs you’d be a real-life
Eeyore, but without the lows you’d be a

488.text:
reckless bouncing ball of sunshine. Which
brings us to…

497.text:
Every day we’re bombarded with well-meaning
but borderline sugary messages like “Be

502.text:
happy! Stay positive! Don’t be such a Debbie
Downer!” But, as you may suspect, this is

509.text:
Negative emotions are hardwired in us as a
sort-of leftover from the days when we had

514.text:
to defend ourselves from the likes of saber-toothed
tigers. While these types of emotions can

519.text:
harm us if they’re left to stew and simmer,
they can also push us to make the most out

523.text:
of a bad day, as a study from the University
of Liverpool suggests. In fact, according

528.text:
to that same study, people who are “too
compassionate” (yes, that’s totally a

532.text:
thing) feel emotional stress from basically
being human shock-absorbers to other people’s

537.text:
Bottom line: To be emotionally healthy, allow
yourself to experience both positive and negative

543.text:
emotions. Once you’ve calmed down a bit,
think about why you’re experiencing them,

547.text:
use your judgment to decide the best course
of action at the moment, and do it!
